Searching with a vector with some filter would be faster than scroll with a filter, as it could utilize the HNSW graph for it. But then you'd have to have some vector, which doesn't work for your use case.
And still, `retrieve` would be magnitudes faster.

A very rough analogy may be this: imagine having an array of 1 million points with data attached.

- `retrieve` would pick out the right point instantly by accessing it by it's index (point ID).
- `filter` on `scroll` will have to go through **all** points one by one, and test whether it matches the point you're requesting.

Again, this is very rough and doesn't match internals, but I hope this gets the point across.

That's right. Retrieve should be a lot faster.

Basically, `retrieve` with a point ID leads us to a point directly. 
`filter` on `scroll` will have to go through all points with their metadata, and try to match the filter to see which is the correct one.

Exactly, the question is "if I store the point IDs as metadata and use it as the filter, would it be equivalent to `retrieve()` in performance."

You have answered the question, as `retrieve` would be faster üôÇ 

Do you mind explaining why? What is the difference in the two approaches from an algorithmic perspective?

Hi

1) Sparse does not have "weights" field
2) You can use pydantic models instead of dicts to be sure

As it is reflected in the `upsert`'s signature, it accepts `types.Points`

`types.Points` -> `Union[rest.Batch, List[Union[rest.PointStruct, grpc.PointStruct]]]`

`rest.Batch` ->  ```python
class Batch(BaseModel, extra="forbid"):
    ids: List["ExtendedPointId"] = Field(..., description="")
    vectors: "BatchVectorStruct" = Field(..., description="")
    payloads: Optional[List["Payload"]] = Field(default=None, description="")```

`BatchVectorStruct` -> ```python
Union[
    List[List[StrictFloat]],
    Dict[StrictStr, List[Vector]],
]
```
`Vector` -> ```python
Vector = Union[
    SparseVector,
    List[StrictFloat],
]
```

`SparseVector` -> ```python
class SparseVector(BaseModel, extra="forbid"):
    """
    Sparse vector structure
    """

    indices: List[int] = Field(..., description="indices must be unique")
    values: List[float] = Field(..., description="values and indices must be the same length")
```

Btw, pydantic v2 has significantly increased speed of upsert and search operations due to a faster serialization

I'd recommend you to check whether you can tweak your dependencies to be compatible with pydantic v2 for a better performance

it is fine for qdrant to keep second index in payload. And yes, we recommend to index all fields that are used in filtering

> How does memory management work in Qdrant? Suppose we run our instance as a Docker container and each collection is memory-mapped. Suppose also that our data does not fully fit in the allocated memory. Is there a caching policy to swap out collections or segments in this case (and if so what is it)? How is this affected by the large number of collections that our use case requires?

Qdrant relies on the Kernel-level memory management with mmaps. In practice it means, that OS will try to use as much disk cache as possible, but when RAM is not enough it will evict memory pages that are least accessed.

You can configure qdrant to store almost everything in mmaps  - one expection for how in payload index, but it usually much smaller than vectors

>  I could imagine emulating the isolation above by querying on metadata, but these queries tend to degrade performance. How is metadata filtering implemented? All I could  find on the subject is: https://qdrant.tech/articles/filtrable-hnsw/ but it is unclear if this is the currently used approach and how performant it is.

Yes, this is currently used approach, we use it especially to combat the retrieval degradation with filtering. But it actually goes even deeper and allow you to only build sub-graphs for each tenant, avoiding costs of global HNSW building

>  isolated collection of vectors, for various reasons, such as improved retrieval, access permissions etc

There are no difference in access permissions if you are using collections vs payload filtering. Pretty much the same way as you don't create a table for each user in relational databases. 

Isolation makes sense if you have large customers. In this case you cna always move them into separate collection, but if you only need to store one video transcription - a dedicated collection will have a huge overhead.

content:
Hi!

We, at Augmend (https://augmend.com/), are looking into Qdrant as a vectorDB solution for our product. Our platform, among other functionalities, allows one or more users to hold a video conference. During the conference, our system records content from various sources and converts it to embeddings.

I'd like to learn more about Qdrant and see if it is a good fit with our system. Here are a couple of questions:

- Ideally we would like each meeting to be encapsulated in an isolated collection of vectors, for various reasons, such as improved retrieval, access permissions etc. I was looking at one of the threads from earlier today that mentioned too many collections being an anti-pattern in Qdrant. I am curious to hear your thoughts about our use case.

- As a follow up question, I am also curious to learn more about the metadata filtering approach that Qdrant takes. I could imagine emulating the isolation above by querying on metadata, but these queries tend to degrade performance. How is metadata filtering implemented? All I could  find on the subject is: https://qdrant.tech/articles/filtrable-hnsw/ but it is unclear if this is the currently used approach and how performant it is.

- How does memory management work in Qdrant? Suppose we run our instance as a Docker container and each collection is memory-mapped. Suppose also that our data does not fully fit in the allocated memory. Is there a caching policy to swap out collections or segments in this case (and if so what is it)? How is this affected by the large number of collections that our use case requires? Will this guarantee that the instance never runs out of memory and fails?

I am looking forwards to hearing your thoughts.

Thanks!

HI luecu, 
Unfortunately, Fully scaling down a cluster is not supported, as block storage can only be scaled up.
However, you can take snapshots of the collections, create a new cluster, and restore the collections there. Then you can delete your old cluster
https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/snapshots/

The other option would be that you pick another package, and we manually scale down the cluster's RAM and CPU for you. 
In this case you'll still be charged for the disk of the older package (since it can not be scaled down).
I hope this helps, let me know if you have any more questions and how you would like to move forward.

content: With `/` it is not aware of any consensus states. So if a pod has restarted it is marked as ready immediately, even though it might still have to catch up to the rest of the nodes. content: Your Qdrant Cloud interface should show the current memory usage in a chart.
The best way to do this is to measure actual memory currently used memory with the current number of points, and make your own estimations from there.
It is basically impossible to accuratly calculate the memory usage based on the number of points. The above formula is very  rough, and the actual result may be a bit higher or lower.

When Qdrant Cloud's memory usage approaches 100%, the cluster becomes unresponsive. Therefore, I infer the memory usage from the number of points and an alert goes off when it exceeds 80%.

I use a simple formula written on the official website, but this seems to have a large margin of error.
`memory_size = number_of_active_vectors * vector_dimension * 4 bytes * 1.5`

Are there any other techniques to know the current memory usage?

content:
> How can I control the size of each node in both GKE autopilot and if not appropriate GKE standard (e.g. size of RAM and disk space per node).

For autopilot, you only have to adjust the resource requests on the containers. In our helm chart, that's here: 
https://github.com/qdrant/qdrant-helm/blob/main/charts/qdrant/values.yaml#L85-L91

For a regular GKE cluster, you need to make sure to have a node pool that can host the qdrant cluster (depends on how much resources you define). Keep in mind that every GKE will reserve some resources for the OS, i.e. a n1-standard-2 (2cores/7.5gb) you only have roughly 1.8c/5.7gb available for pods/containers.

The helm chart can be used on both, GKE autopilot & regular GKE. 

> Also, do I need to deploy a loadbalaner on GKE to publicly access qdrant or is this handled by the helm chart? 

As Andrey mentioned, the helm chart does not provide an ingress.
The GKE documentation has a great document on using the ingress controller that GKE provides: https://cloud.google.com/kubernetes-engine/docs/concepts/ingress

@null one small change to make when using the example version for the first time - change `RecreateCollectionAsync(...)` to `CreateCollectionAsync(...)`. There's a small bug in the client that will be fixed with this PR: https://github.com/qdrant/qdrant-dotnet/pull/37

content:
Yesterday, we encountered a significant issue with our system. We started receiving 503 service unavailable errors. Upon inspecting the logs, it was clear that we were running out of memory.
The metrics indicated a continuous increase in RAM usage without any subsequent decrease. After restarting the cluster, the issue persisted. It was only resolved when we deleted all the collections.
In our app, we utilize 'knowledge bases', which can consist of one or multiple embedded files. Our approach has been to create a new collection for each knowledge base.
According to our research and documentation review, it's recommended to store all knowledge bases in a single collection, using fields like knowledgebase_id in the payload. This approach should include filtering that field for context retrieval of the wanted knowledge base. Also, we found that using In Disk storage and indexing on the knowledgebase_id field will help us mitigate this issue.
We're considering implementing these changes and possibly exploring quantization if necessary.
We would greatly appreciate your insights and suggestions on this situation. Any additional best practices or improvements are welcome.
thanks!

hey Zara nice seeing you here üëã 

I recommend using qdrant-helm to deploy on k8s on whatever your cloud, whether AWS or anything else. if you are trying to maximize throughput of reads on a single collection, then replicating it across nodes would achieve that. 

also not sure what locking behavior you are referring to

Are shard replicas automatically placed on different nodes in a cluster?

For example, in the example in https://qdrant.tech/documentation/guides/distributed_deployment/#replication-factor if the cluster has 6 nodes, and the create collection request specifies 6 shards and replication factor 2, is it guaranteed that none of the two replicated shards would be placed on the same node?

The intention is to ensure fault tolerance of any one node. If it was not guaranteed that replicas were placed on different nodes, then to achieve this behavior it seems one would have to do this manually by creating multiple shards and moving them to differing nodes.

Not able to find docs explaining this clearly.
